column16: # for nominatives of all kinds
# for times and events in nominative, among other uses
# for physical things in dative, ablative, and locative
# for observables in accusative
# for audibles in accusative
# a catch all for directing attention to/from/near observables, audibles, concepts, and really anything
# russian translation is closer to "aim"
# old english translation is closer to "steer"
# sanskrit translation is closer to "lead"
# PIE translation is closer to "pull" or "lead"
# greek translation is closer to "straighten"
# for propositional case only
# for concepts in accusative that can be attributed as good
# sanskrit descendants of PIE *lubʰ all turned to mean "desire", "prīṇā́ti" is used instead which means "to be pleased"
# Sanskrit is derived from PIE for "to fear"
# for concepts in accusative that can be attributed neither to good nor bad
# PIE is hypothesized based upon proto-germanic formations, lit. "by-thinking"
# for observables in instrumental
# proto indo european translation roughly means "to right oneself"
# sanskri translation roughly means "to direct" or "to steer"
# for times in dative and ablative
